awd_titl_txt: EAGER/Collaborative Research: Challenging the Cognitive-Control Divide
awd_abstract_narration:
This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) collaborative research project is between an expert in robotics and control theory and an expert in experimental and computational motor neuroscience. It bridges cognitive science, experimental psychology and control engineering. The intellectual premise of the work is that a quantitative theory of human cognition may be built on top of limiting cases of human motor function. This premise lays the foundation for the development of a comprehensive quantitative theory of control-relevant cognition. The result will be an invaluable tool for the human-friendly design of complex motion control systems. Control strategies based on these fundamental objects would be more intuitively understandable by human operators, including prediction of impending failure. Extension of the results beyond motion control provide a new class of knowledge-processing systems capable of more natural interactions with humans. 

The objective of this project is to articulate and test a quantitative, control-relevant theory of human cognition, to address a growing divide between cognitive science and control theory. The core hypothesis is that cognitive functions emerged from and are constrained by neural structures used for motor control. Complex motor actions are composed from a limited "library" of dynamic primitives, defined as attractors (e.g. fixed points, limit cycles, etc.). The project postulates that a similar composition of dynamic primitives underlies cognitive processes and that quantitative details may be obtained by re-purposing dynamic primitives found in motor behavior, especially in the manipulation of complex objects such as tools where the link between motor and cognitive function may be strongest. The project is based on a novel series of experiments: A data series is generated by various human participants physically manipulating a complex dynamic object. Alternative data sets are generated by computer simulation of movements to the same targets that minimize mean-squared applied force. Random fluctuations generated by low-pass filtered zero-mean Gaussian white noise and of magnitude comparable to the fluctuations in human performance are added to the simulated force and motion time-series. Without being told the origin, a second set of subjects are presented with the results as evolving abstract time-series and asked to predict their outcome. Subsequently, they are asked to generate a control input for the abstract system, based on their experience, to accomplish a specified task. According to the hypothesis, the subjects will more successfully predict the outcome of human-controlled systems than the synthetic systems, and will generate control inputs that more closely match the human-controlled system inputs.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

The main goals of this collaborative project were to develop and validate a theory that human cognition has a modular structure analogous to that observed in motor behavior. The theory is that both cognition and motor behavior are organized as a hierarchy of dynamic primitives. These primitives are described mathematically as dynamic attractors which emerge from collective neural behavior. The key idea is that dynamic primitives observed in motor behavior are "re-purposed" for cognition.

In collaboration with Prof. Dagmar Sternad of Northeastern University, we jointly designed and conducted experiments to assess human subjects' cognitive and motor performance. Specifically, we assessed subjects' ability to:

1) Predict and physically cooperate with a robot's actions;

2) Control physical interaction at very slow speeds; and

3) Perceive arm stiffness based on purely visual information.

In the first experiment we found that humans cooperated more effectively with a robot when it exhibited human-like motion patterns. The robot traced an elliptical path while the human attempted to follow along, exerting near-zero force. This represented one possible form of human-robot collaboration. Human subjects' ability to cooperate with the robot was significantly better when the robot trajectory was "biomimetic", following a speed-curvature relation that is robustly observed in human movements. With training on other speed-curvature relations, performance improved but never exceeded that observed with the biomimetic trajectory. Because there was ample time (3 seconds for each circuit of the elliptical path) for reactive (feedback-based) corrections, subjects' sensitivity to the speed-curvature relation indicates that humans rely heavily on prediction--a cognitive activity--to perform this task. That prediction is consistent with our theory of dynamic primitives.

In all cases, human subjects' ability to control force exerted while moving was profoundly limited, even when the robot followed a biomimetic trajectory (the easiest case). That is consistent with our theory that humans do not control force directly, but encode physical interaction in terms of motion and mechanical impedance (one of the dynamic primitives). Also consistent with our theory, we found that, though slow movements should be more precise (as there is more time for feedback-based corrections) we found the opposite: moving slowly is hard for humans.

Conversely, we found that humans have a remarkable ability to perceive multi-joint limb stiffness (a key component of interactive dynamics) without physical contact, solely based on a visual display of motion. The theory was used to articulate how humans could assess arm stiffness without physical contact. Importantly, the visual display that simulated arm motion was driven by dynamic primitives, exhibiting motion patterns determined by joint stiffness.

Taken together, our results support our theory that dynamic primitives observed in motor behavior underlie at least some aspects of cognitive function, including prediction and perception. The theory revealed hitherto under-explored limitations of human motor performance (the challenge of slow movements) and cognitive performance (the challenge of deviating from biological speed-curvature relations. The theory also supports surprising human cognitive abilities (to identify joint stiffness without physical contact). The theory provides a new, quantitative, mathematically-formulated perspective on the old idea of "embodied cognition" as a description of human cognitive performance. Our experiments to date validate the theory.

The results of this research have been presented in 5 archival journal papers, 1 book chapter, and 8 conference presentations.

Broader Impacts

Our theory suggested a novel and especially efficient approach to robot programming. This is the basis of a US patent application: "Compositional Impedance Programming for Robots" Neville Hogan and Lucille Hosford. Patent Application Publication US 2018/0236659 A1, August 23, 2018.

Our results on non-contact stiffness estimation may provide a new quantitative assessment of abnormal tone and spasticity, sorely needed by the physical medicine and rehabilitation community.

The MIT component of this collaborative project influenced the professional development of 1 post-doctoral trainee, 3 pre-doctoral graduate student research assistants and 5 undergraduate (pre-baccalaureate) students. Those persons included one under-represented minority, and three females, improving their motivation to continue in research in science, technology, engineering and mathematics.
